fMRI study examining social-cognitive processing of personal attribute evaluations (perception/understanding of self), with individual differences in healthy participants implied. Abstract does not specify ages but meets the review objective; insufficient details on age/sample warrant inclusion for full-text screening.

fMRI study in healthy adult humans (N=55 males) performing a social-related task (direct vs. averted gaze), measuring amygdala BOLD response. Meets inclusion criteria (social processing, healthy adults). Not a review. Pharmacological/genetic features do not exclude inclusion.

Resting-state fMRI study without participants performing a social-related task. Although healthy controls are included, the meta-analysis requires task-based fMRI during social processing; abstract therefore does not meet inclusion criteria.
All participants were children (ages 7–12). Inclusion requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 17–65, which is not met. Study is not a review.

Resting-state fMRI in male adolescents with conduct disorder (patient group); no task-based social-processing paradigm and participants are adolescents rather than healthy adults aged 17–65. Does not meet the review’s requirement for task-based social-related fMRI in healthy adult participants.

The study reports MEG (magnetoencephalography) hyperscanning with dual MEG recordings, not functional MRI. It therefore does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring an fMRI scan during social-related tasks.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants examining perception of others’ social interactions (third-person perspective) using biological motion; task involves social-related processing (responses to typical vs atypical social actions). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.

fMRI study in 22 healthy adult participants examining processing of CT-targeted affective (social) touch; task assesses social perception/cognition (insula, STS, mPFC), matches inclusion criteria and is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

Study uses resting-state fMRI in schizophrenia patients; no task-based fMRI of social processing is reported, and it does not focus on healthy adults performing a social-related task. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI BOLD study of affective and cognitive Theory of Mind (social cognition) in 23 healthy participants fits review objective of social-related processing in healthy adults. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient evidence of task-based fMRI in healthy humans; include for full-text extraction.

fMRI study investigating neural responses to observing social interactions and gaze, addressing social cognition/perception of others. Participants are human (presumably healthy adults); task is social-related. Not a review. Abstract lacks explicit age range, but criteria permit inclusion for full-text confirmation; include for full-text review.

The study used resting-state fMRI after cTBS rather than an fMRI scan during a social-related task. Although action observation/execution was used to localize the target, the primary data are resting-state connectivity, so it does not meet the task-based social fMRI inclusion criterion.

Abstract reports fMRI changes related to an implied social presence but does not state that participants performed a social-related task or provide participant ages/health. Information is insufficient to determine eligibility from abstract alone; include for full-text review to assess task details and participant characteristics.
Animal (rat) study using resting-state fMRI under anesthesia; not conducted in human participants and does not involve a social-task fMRI in healthy adults. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract addresses Theory of Mind (social cognition) relevant to review but does not specify that an fMRI was conducted or report participant characteristics (healthy adults, ages). Insufficient methodological detail to determine eligibility — include for full-text review.

fMRI study examines social-related processing (empathy/attachment—self, loved-one, stranger perspectives) using task-based imaging. Appears to involve healthy adult participants; not a review. Abstract lacks explicit age/health details, so include for full-text verification.

fMRI was conducted in healthy adult medical doctors (ages 25–37) during a social interaction task (doctor–patient treatment) probing empathy/compassion and reward-related processing, matching the review objective of social-related fMRI in healthy adults; not a review article.

Double-blind placebo-controlled fMRI in 55 healthy young men (within 17–65) using social-related stimuli (attachment-related erotic scenes and fearful social scenes). Study examines social processing and neural activation; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI was conducted while healthy adult participants performed a social-cognitive task about kin and friends, which fits the review objective. The abstract does not report participant ages, but includes healthy adults; no exclusion criteria apply. Include for full-text review to confirm ages and other details.

fMRI study comparing self-reference vs reference to others—directly addresses social cognition. Abstract describes task-based fMRI in human participants and is not a review. Participant health/age not specified; per guidance, include for full-text review when unclear.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (mothers) performing a social-related task (viewing own vs. unfamiliar child/dog) probing affiliation/attachment and social cognition. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes an fMRI study using the Eyes task assessing theory of mind/social cognition, which fits the social-related task criterion. However the abstract does not state participant ages or clearly indicate a healthy adult group (17–65). Insufficient details to exclude; include for full-text review to confirm participant age and health status.

Study uses fMRI to examine self- and other-reflection (social processing) but abstract does not specify presence of a healthy control group. Include for full-text review to confirm whether healthy adults (age 17–65) were scanned.

Double-blind randomized crossover fMRI study in 18 healthy adult males performing a validated social cognition (Theory of Mind; Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test) task. Fits inclusion criteria (fMRI during social-related task in healthy adults); not a review.

Study used fMRI while participants performed a gaze-following task (a social attention/Perception of Others paradigm) investigating group/in‑group effects and ideological attitudes. It involves human voters (presumably healthy adults) and is an original empirical study, not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults.

fMRI was used while participants (including a matched healthy adult control group) thought about social interactions—a social-related task addressing self/other representation. Participants are adults and healthy controls are present, meeting inclusion criteria. Not a review.

Study uses fMRI to examine Theory of Mind (a social cognition task) comparing euthymic bipolar patients with healthy subjects, indicating presence of a healthy adult control group and a social-related fMRI task. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient evidence to include for full-text review.

fMRI was used while healthy adult participants performed a social perception task examining in-group vs out-group bias in action perception, directly targeting social-related processing (perception of others). Not a review/meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria.

Task-based fMRI study examining theory-of-mind/social cognition during cooperation vs. competition—clearly a social-related task. Not a review/meta-analysis. Although participant ages not specified in the abstract, the study appears to involve healthy adult participants; meets inclusion for fMRI social processing. Include for full-text data extraction.

Participants were patients with amnestic mild cognitive impairment and no healthy adult control group is reported. Inclusion requires at least one group of healthy participants (age 17–65). Although the task involves face-name social stimuli, the absence of healthy participants excludes the study.

fMRI study probing empathy for others’ pain (social cognition). Includes a healthy young participant group aged 20–30, which meets the 17–65 inclusion age criterion. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.

fMRI study investigating social brain connectivity and social symptom correlations; includes a group of typically developing (healthy) adolescents. However, ages are unspecified (adolescents may be <17), and inclusion criterion requires healthy adults 17–65. Abstract insufficient to confirm adult ages, so include for full-text review.

This is a resting-state fMRI study (no task) investigating cerebro-cerebellar limbic networks in AD/MCI. It does not involve task-based social processing in healthy adults, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in 18 healthy subjects investigating perspective-taking/empathy (social cognition: perception/understanding of others). Meets inclusion of social-related task and healthy participants; not a review/meta-analysis. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text confirmation.

fMRI study of perception/understanding of others (observing goal-directed hand actions) involving healthy participants (n=31). This is a social-perception task and includes a healthy adult group, meeting inclusion criteria. Age range not specified in abstract but likely adults; full text can confirm if needed.

Study used fMRI during a social/mentalizing task (Domino interactive task) and includes a typically developed healthy control group aged 18–34, meeting the review’s age and healthy-participant criteria. Not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study investigating processing of dynamic vs static facial expressions (social perception) and includes age- and sex-matched typically developing control group. Abstract does not specify participant ages (17–65), so insufficient info to confirm age criterion; include for full-text review to verify age and other details.

Abstract reports an event-related fMRI study using dynamic naturalistic videos contrasting social vs. nonsocial gestures, directly addressing social processing. No indication it is a review/meta-analysis. Participant health/ages are not specified in the abstract; therefore include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adult (17–65) group and other eligibility details.

Abstract reports an fMRI study manipulating sociality and social working memory (social cognition/face processing). It addresses social-related processing in humans. Participant health/ages aren’t specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm at least one healthy adult group (17–65).

Study participants are adolescents (typically developing and TBI groups), not healthy adults aged 17–65 required by the review. Although it uses an fMRI social cognition task, the healthy group is under the target age range, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of self-referential processing (social-related: perception/understanding of self) that includes a healthy control group. Abstract does not report participant ages; insufficient to confirm they fall within 17–65. Include for full-text review to confirm age range and other methodological details.

fMRI study measuring Theory of Mind (a social cognitive task) with both bipolar patients and a healthy-control group (n=25). This meets the requirement of an fMRI social-related task and includes healthy adult participants; not a review.

fMRI study using MVPA examining neural organization of mental-state representation (social cognition: understanding others). Human participants implied; not a review. Abstract lacks explicit participant ages/health status, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

fMRI study in human participants examining mirror neuron activity and the influence of emotional valence on visuomotor associations, addressing social cognition/perception of others. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is an original empirical study (not a review), meeting inclusion criteria.

Participants were healthy children/adolescents aged 10–17 with no adult (17–65) group reported. The meta-analysis requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 17–65, so the study does not meet inclusion criteria.

Participants are preschool-aged children with ASD (and TD controls), not healthy adults aged 17–65. Although task is social-related, the sample does not include healthy adult participants, so it fails the age/group inclusion criterion.

Event-related fMRI study of moral reasoning (a social-cognitive task) with a matched group of 28 healthy subjects. Meets inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI in healthy adults); not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study using a joint-attention social task examining representation of what another person sees—clearly assesses social cognition/perception of others in humans. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and does not meet any exclusion criteria. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of body-checking/self-perception (relevant to ‘Perception and Understanding of Self’) but does not state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Because the presence of healthy participants is unclear from the abstract, include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study with 26 participants performing empathy-evoking film clips addressing social cognition (empathic concern, integration of contextual emotional information). Abstract does not explicitly state participant ages/health, but it clearly meets the review's topic and should be included for full-text review to confirm age range and healthy sample.

This is a protocol for a systematic review/meta-analysis of oxytocin fMRI studies, not an original fMRI study with human participants performing a social-related task. Per exclusion criteria, systematic reviews/meta-analyses are excluded.

Sample comprises 9–17-year-olds (N=34); no separate adult group within the review’s required 17–65 age range is reported. Although an fMRI social task was used, the participants are adolescents, not the healthy adults targeted by the review.

Empirical fMRI study with 20 healthy adult volunteers performing a social-related task (simulating a boxer's feelings), investigating perception/understanding of others via action-observation network. Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults.

The study used fMRI (dual‑fMRI) during cooperative and competitive social interactions, directly addressing social processing. The abstract does not specify participant age or explicitly state participants were healthy adults, so inclusion cannot be confirmed from abstract alone; include for full‑text review to verify health status and age range.

fMRI study in healthy adults examining understanding of actions at different levels (why/how) that engages mental-state reasoning and action-representation networks; this probes social-cognitive processing (perception/understanding of others). Not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study examining mentalizing (social cognition) during tasks about self/other; includes a healthy adult control group (33 age- and IQ-matched controls). Not a review/meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults.

fMRI was conducted while participants performed the Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test, a social-cognitive task assessing perception/understanding of others. Sample comprises healthy young adult women (N=16) within the 17–65 range. Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

Original BOLD fMRI study examining social-related processing (affiliation vs isolation) while participants made pleasantness judgments. Involves healthy younger and older adult groups (younger adults likely within 17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study in healthy young adults using an incentive delay task with social rewards; directly examines neural correlates of social reward processing (anticipation and feedback), meeting the review’s population and task criteria. Not a review article.

fMRI study of facial perception and expression processing in human observers—fits social perception/communication objective. Likely healthy adults; abstract lacks explicit ages/health details, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

The study used task-free (resting-state) fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. Although the ATL is discussed in relation to social cognition, no social-related task was performed; thus it does not meet the requirement for fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults.

fMRI study with 20 healthy adult participants (single group) performing face and voice perception tasks, which are social-communication/perception of others constructs. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in normal adult volunteers viewing dynamic social interactions (positive/negative social encounters). This meets the social-related task criterion and includes healthy adults (normal volunteers). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.

Original fMRI study where participants performed a social task (sex-categorization of interacting person dyads). Not a review. Abstract does not specify participant age/health, so insufficient to confirm but meets the review topic; include for full-text review.

This is an fMRI study of face processing (social perception/understanding of others) with a healthy control group (21 adults) performing encoding/recognition of faces during scanning. It meets the review’s requirement for social-related fMRI in healthy adults. Age range not specified in abstract—full text can confirm ages if needed.

Participants are adult male incarcerated offenders; abstract does not report any healthy control group or healthy participants aged 17–65. Although it used task-based fMRI of social processing, inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (40 heterosexual males) examining neural and behavioral responses to interpersonal touch (a social/affiliative communication task). It reports task-related neural activity and behavioral outcomes relevant to social processing and is not a review, meeting inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in healthy adult men during social-related tasks (face/gaze processing; theory of mind and fear-recognition), matching the review objective and inclusion criteria. Not a review/meta-analysis. Sufficient detail in abstract to include for full-text data extraction.

The study reports fMRI in a developmental sample of children and adolescents with no adult group aged 17–65; therefore it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy adult (17–65) participant group.

This is an fMRI study in healthy human participants (N=25) examining facial color processing, which informs social communication and perception of others—directly relevant to the review’s social-related processing constructs. No exclusion criteria met. Although the abstract does not state participants’ ages explicitly, the study appears to involve typical adult participants; include for full-text review to confirm ages and other details.

fMRI study in healthy volunteers examining evaluative processes of guilt and embarrassment (social/self-conscious emotions), which fits social-related processing in adults; not a review. Age range not stated but participants described as healthy volunteers—include for full-text to confirm ages and details.
Participants are preadolescent children (age 11), falling well below the required adult age range (17–65) for inclusion in this review of healthy adult fMRI studies.

fMRI study examining neural correlates of social understanding in high-functioning adults; includes a healthy adult control group (n=23). Participants are adults and the task involves social processing. Not a review/meta-analysis—meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study measured brain activity during a social interactive task versus a non-social control, addressing social cognition in humans. Participants appear to be healthy adults (no clinical populations reported), but ages are not specified in the abstract. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.
All participants described are individuals with schizophrenia (AT+SCT N=11, CG N=11); no healthy adult group is reported. Inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group aged 17–65.

Abstract reports an fMRI mentalizing (social) task but does not state inclusion of a healthy control group aged 17–65; comparison group are nonpsychotic offenders (uncertain health status). Insufficient information to confirm presence of healthy adults, so include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Study used fMRI to measure neural responses during a social reflection task (judgments about self and others) in 22 healthy subjects, directly matching the review objective. Not a review/meta-analysis. Although exact ages not reported in abstract, participants are described as healthy (likely adults); include for full-text if age needs confirmation.

Abstract reports effects of intranasal oxytocin on face processing in adults with Asperger syndrome only; it does not mention any healthy control group or inclusion of healthy participants (age 17–65). Fails the requirement of at least one healthy participant group.

fMRI study examining neural correlates of agentic self-evaluation and endorsement of others’ evaluations (perception/understanding of self), which fits social-related processing. Abstract reports whole-brain fMRI analyses and trait self-esteem associations; implies healthy adult sample though ages not specified. No exclusion criteria met; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health.

Event-related fMRI study in human subjects assessing trustworthiness judgments of faces (perception/understanding of others), a social processing task. Not a review. Abstract does not state participant ages explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult (17–65) demographics.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in human participants using a social interaction task (cyber-ball) manipulating social inclusion/exclusion and testing neural responses to partners' faces. This fits social processing in healthy adults; not a review. Sufficient information in abstract to include for full-text review.

Hyperscanning fMRI was used during a real-time joint-attention social interaction, directly addressing social processing. The study involves human dyads and validates cross-brain connectivity related to social behavior; it is empirical (not a review) and likely uses healthy adult participants. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants examining self-recognition (face and name), which is a social-related construct (Perception/Understanding of Self). Methods and population match inclusion criteria and it is an original research article, not a review.

Abstract describes an fMRI study probing social perception/understanding (mirror and mentalizing networks) using interaction stimuli. It appears to involve human participants and addresses social processing. Participant ages/health not specified in abstract; include for full-text review to confirm sample meets 17–65 healthy adults criterion.

Title and methods indicate a multilevel kernel density fMRI analysis (MKDA), a coordinate-based meta-analysis of fMRI studies rather than a primary fMRI experiment with participants. The exclusion criteria rule out meta-analyses/systematic reviews.

Participants are children with benign childhood epilepsy (BCECTS) undergoing fMRI; no healthy adult (age 17–65) group is reported. Thus it does not meet the requirement of including healthy adults 17–65.

The abstract investigates VLPFC white-matter and functional networks supporting memory retrieval using fMRI and diffusion imaging. It does not describe any social-related task or construct (e.g., affiliation, social communication, self/other perception). Therefore it does not meet the review’s inclusion criterion of fMRI during a social-related task.

Abstract reports an fMRI study using social interaction images (social-context emotional stimuli) and includes remitted depressed participants alongside healthy controls (adult sample). It is original research (not a review) and meets criteria for social-related fMRI tasks with healthy adult participants.

Functional MRI was used while participants viewed cooperative vs noncooperative social interactions (a social cognition/theory-of-mind task). The study includes a healthy matched control group (19 adults) alongside patients, and is not a review. Information in the abstract is sufficient to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract does not mention any fMRI imaging; study focuses on autism spectrum conditions and atypical imitation rather than clearly including a healthy adult group (17–65). Lacks required evidence of fMRI in healthy participants.

Study reports fMRI of emotion recognition but includes only schizophrenia outpatients (no healthy participant group). Inclusion requires at least one healthy group aged 17–65, so exclude based on participant population.

fMRI study examining social processes (mimicry, affiliation, group membership, emotional expression). Meets review objective of social-related processing. Abstract does not state participant age/health explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm sample meets healthy adult (17–65) criterion.

fMRI was used during perception of nonverbal emotional social signals (voice and face), a social-related task tapping social communication and perception of others. The abstract implies healthy participants; age range not specified. Include for full-text review to confirm participant demographics and other details.

Study uses fMRI with a social-related face-processing task (dynamic social stimuli). Abstract focuses on schizophrenia patients but does not specify whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Because the abstract is insufficient to confirm presence of healthy participants, include for full-text review to determine eligibility.
Participants are adolescents aged 12–15 with no adult (17–65) healthy group. Although it is an fMRI social-exclusion study, it fails the age eligibility criterion for the review.

fMRI was acquired while healthy participants read a narrative and rated experienced suspense; reported activations are in medial frontal and temporo-parietal regions linked to social cognition and predictive inference. This constitutes social-related processing (perception/understanding of others) in a healthy adult sample, meeting inclusion criteria.

Hyperscanning fMRI was used while participants performed joint-attention tasks probing social cognition/understanding of others. The study investigates social processing in humans and is not a review. Participants appear to be healthy adults; thus it meets the fMRI + social task and healthy participant inclusion criteria.

The study used near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) rather than functional MRI. Inclusion requires an fMRI scan during a social-related task; despite involving healthy adults and a social conversation task, the imaging modality does not meet the criterion.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than scanning participants while they performed a social-related task. Inclusion requires task-based fMRI during a social processing task; therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This is a review article of seven structural and functional MRI studies in ADHD samples (clinical population, likely children/adolescents), not a primary fMRI study of healthy adults. It meets the exclusion criterion for reviews and does not report fMRI of healthy 17–65 participants.

fMRI study investigating person perception and impression updating (social cognition). Participants performed a social task (faces paired with behavioral info). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract implies healthy adult participants; age not listed but criterion allows inclusion if unclear—include for full-text review to confirm demographics.

fMRI hyperscanning study of mutual eye contact in healthy adult pairs; task probes social interaction/perception processes (eye contact, affective/mental state sharing). Participants are healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI was used while participants completed a social-related task (implicit attitudes toward politicians, face/name processing). Results concern social cognition (perception/understanding of others, affiliation). Participants appear to be healthy adults; no review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for meta-analysis.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants investigating co-speech gestures—an aspect of social communication—while watching a narrator; directly examines social-related processing and is empirical (not a review).

Abstract does not report any fMRI data or a social-processing task. It examines gene–environment interactions on response inhibition in adolescents, not a social-related fMRI study in healthy adults (ages 17–65).

Abstract reports an fMRI study addressing self-experience and self-other relationship (social cognition) and includes a healthy control group. However, it does not state whether imaging was acquired during a social-related task or at rest (mentions intrinsic/background connectivity). Insufficient information in abstract to confirm task-based social processing; include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Abstract describes methodological network analysis and differences related to psychosis risk; it does not report an fMRI social-related task or social processing measures. Not focused on social cognition/interaction, so does not meet the review objective.

Resting-state fMRI study with no social-related task performed. Although the abstract mentions networks related to social cognition, it does not involve a task probing social processing. Participants include a clinical (obese) group and lean controls, but lack of task-based social paradigm clearly fails the inclusion criterion.

fMRI study examining perception of different laughter types—clearly social communication/social-cognition processing in humans. No psychiatric/neurological disorders reported. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and other details.

fMRI study (N=26) examining social learning about others’ generosity versus a non-social control; directly addresses social processing. Abstract does not state participant ages or explicit health status, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI was used while adult participants viewed dynamic emotional facial expressions (social perception/understanding of others). The study includes a healthy control group (adults) and is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

All participants were individuals with a psychotic disorder (patients); no healthy control group is reported. Inclusion requires at least one group of healthy adults (17–65). Although fMRI social tasks were used, the absence of healthy participants excludes the study.

Participants are boys (children), not adults; the healthy control is a typically developing boy rather than adults aged 17–65. The study focuses on autism cases and single-case comparisons, not fMRI in healthy adults performing social tasks, so it fails the age/group inclusion criterion.

fMRI study with ‘normal subjects’ performing a social communication task (communicative speech vs description), investigating brain regions involved in social interaction/communication. Fits inclusion criteria (social-related task, healthy participants aged likely 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study of Theory of Mind (social cognition) in healthy adult participants (n=19). Task involved social-related processing (mental state inference and contextual adjustments). Participants are healthy adults within the eligible age range. Not a review or meta-analysis.

Narrative comparative review of face perception across species; not an original human fMRI study. Abstract discusses behavioral and comparative literature rather than reporting fMRI in healthy adult participants performing a social task, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes original fMRI experiments using the Why/How Task to probe Theory of Mind (perception/understanding of others), involving human participants across three studies. It is not a review/meta-analysis and targets social cognition in presumably healthy adults, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examines cortical responses to vocal (social) vs nonvocal sounds and compares individuals with autism to a normal activation pattern, implying a healthy control group. It addresses social-related auditory processing. Abstract does not state participant ages (17–65), so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and other eligibility details.

Participants are children/adolescents (young adolescents) including an autism group and typically developing adolescents; no healthy adult (age 17–65) group is reported. Therefore it does not meet the requirement of at least one healthy adult participant group.

Human fMRI study examining perception of social signals (facial expressions and social approach), clearly addressing social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). No indication study is a review or involves only clinical populations; likely healthy adult participants. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Study used resting-state fMRI to assess biomarkers in individuals with autism; no task-based social processing paradigm described and focus is clinical ASD rather than healthy adults performing social tasks.
Participants are children and adolescents (ages 8–17). No adult-only group within the required 17–65 age range is reported, so the study does not meet the adult participant criterion for inclusion.
This is a resting-state fMRI study in ultra-high-risk (clinical) subjects with no task-based social processing reported and no clear healthy adult task group; does not meet inclusion criteria.

Study used fMRI during a face-perception task with emotional/neutral stimuli (social cognition/perception of others) and includes a healthy control group alongside social phobia patients. Not a review/meta-analysis. Age not reported in abstract—include for full-text verification.

Resting-state fMRI was used (no social-related task). Inclusion requires a task-based social processing paradigm; although healthy adults and oxytocin/social cognition are relevant, absence of a social task excludes the study.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social perception comparing ASD and typically developing adolescents, involving social-related tasks and healthy (typically developing) participants. However, participant ages are not specified in the abstract, so it is unclear whether healthy participants fall within the 17–65 range. Include for full-text review to confirm age range and other eligibility details.

fMRI study examining processing of social reputation (social-related task) in male and female subjects; appears to involve healthy adult participants and targets social cognition (vmPFC responses). No exclusion criteria met. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

fMRI study in 20 healthy human participants performing a social-related mimicry task modulated by eye contact. Directly examines social processing (mimicry, eye contact) in healthy adults and is an original empirical study (not a review). Ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text confirmation.

Abstract reports neural activation during social cognitive tasks in patients and their unaffected siblings, implying inclusion of healthy adults (unaffected siblings) and social-related processing; likely used fMRI though not explicitly stated. Abstract lacks explicit mention of fMRI, so include for full-text review to confirm methods and participant ages.
Participants are non-human (dogs); review requires fMRI studies in human adults (age 17–65). Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Primary fMRI study with 28 healthy adult participants performing a social interaction simulation probing friendship (affiliation/empathy/reward). Task is social-related; adults within target age range; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.

The study addresses social perception (evaluation of face approachability), fitting the review objective. However the abstract does not explicitly state that fMRI was used or specify participant ages/health. Include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality and healthy adult sample.

Provides fMRI data collected while healthy adult participants performed social-related tasks (emotion discrimination and affective priming involving facial/vocal expressions). Addresses social communication and perception of others; not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study examining neural representations of empathy for familiar vs unfamiliar others in (presumably) healthy adult participants; task is social (empathy/other perception). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI during social cognition tasks (empathy, forgivability) but does not state presence of a healthy control/group of healthy adults. Insufficient information to confirm required healthy participant group; include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

The healthy participant group comprises typically developing adolescents (ages 12–19); no healthy adult sample within the required 17–65 age range is reported. Thus it does not meet the inclusion criterion of a healthy participant group aged 17–65.

Human functional MRI study investigating affiliative/kinship-related social scenarios. Abstract indicates neuroimaging of affiliative emotion in humans (presumably healthy adult participants) and is not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of 36 healthy human subjects performing a social-related task (observing cooperative and affective social interactions) addressing perception/understanding of others. Participants are healthy adults; study is original empirical fMRI research, not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

The article is a meta-analysis/systematic review of fMRI studies. The exclusion criteria explicitly exclude systematic reviews or meta-analyses, so it should be excluded despite addressing social-related fMRI tasks in healthy adults.

The study used resting-state fMRI (ALFF and RSFC) to examine trait self-esteem and did not involve participants performing a social-related task. Inclusion requires task-based fMRI during a social-related task; thus it should be excluded.

fMRI study focuses on children (high-functioning ASD vs typically developing children), not adults. Inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group aged 17–65. Therefore it does not meet the age criterion for inclusion.

fMRI study of prayer in a group of (presumably healthy) adult Danish Christians; task (praying) engages social-cognition regions (mPFC, TPJ, precuneus), fitting ‘perception/understanding of others’ social processing. Meets fMRI + social-task + healthy adult group criteria. Age range not stated but participants described as a general adult group; include for full-text review.

Abstract discusses brain activation related to social cognition but does not explicitly state that fMRI was used or whether a healthy control group (ages 17–65) was included. Information is insufficient from the abstract alone, so include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

fMRI study of social processing (learning others' trustworthiness) in healthy younger and older adults. Younger group likely falls within 17–65, meeting inclusion; no exclusion criteria met and abstract clearly reports task-based fMRI of social cognition.

Event-related fMRI using a false-belief task probes understanding of others’ mental states (social cognition). Not a review. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health explicitly; include for full-text review to confirm that healthy adults (17–65) were studied and to extract details.

Abstract reports use of real-time fMRI combined with EEG to train social communication skills targeting the right STS, addressing social-related processing. However, participant characteristics (healthy adults aged 17–65) and task details are not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI was conducted while participants performed a social-related task (Multifaceted Empathy Test). The study includes 50 age- and gender-matched healthy control participants (adult range implied) alongside BPD patients and is not a review. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study probing social cognition/empathy (receiving empathic vs. unempathic feedback) in healthy adult participants (n=20). Task clearly involves social-related processing (emotional and cognitive empathy). No indication of clinical sample or that this is a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining neural responses to witnessing an emergency (bystander effect), a social influence on helping behavior—clearly a social-related task. Abstract implies experimental fMRI in human participants; although ages/health status aren’t specified, inclusion should proceed for full-text verification of participant demographics (healthy adults 17–65).

Study used fMRI to compare responses to familiar vs unfamiliar faces (social processing: perception/understanding of others) and included an age-matched healthy control group. It is an original empirical case study (not a review), so meets inclusion criteria.

This article is an activation likelihood estimation meta-analysis (a meta-analysis/systematic review) rather than an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. Exclusion criterion disallows systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study of social communication (viewing, imitating, producing facial expressions and social hand gestures) in human participants. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit health status; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Event-related fMRI study of evaluative judgments (self-referential processing/theory of mind), a social-related task, and includes healthy age-matched control subjects (young adults). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Primary fMRI study in humans examining social processing (mPFC responses to social groups and individuation). Participants performed social-related tasks (age estimation vs. food-preference judgments). No indication it is a review; likely healthy adult participants. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Participants are described as early adolescent girls (adolescence), indicating a sample younger than 17. The meta-analysis requires healthy participants aged 17–65. Although the study uses fMRI and social tasks, the age criterion is not met based on the abstract.

Abstract reports fMRI during a social task (honesty/trust) directly relevant to social processing. Participant health/age not specified in abstract, so insufficient info; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study of mentalizing/theory-of-mind (social cognition) in humans, directly addressing the review objective. The abstract does not report participant ages or explicitly state healthy adult sample; include for full-text review to confirm participants meet the 17–65 healthy adult criterion and other eligibility details.

Abstract reports fMRI during a facial imitate/observe task (a social processing paradigm) and explicitly includes participants “with and without severe mental illness,” indicating a healthy/control group. Although ages are not specified in the abstract, the study addresses social-related processing in humans. Include for full-text review to confirm age range and extract data.
Participants are children (typically developing and ASD children); meta-analysis requires healthy adult participants aged 17–65. Age mismatch excludes the study despite fMRI social processing task.

fMRI study investigating perception/understanding of self vs others (self-recognition) using images of own and others' body parts; fits social-related processing constructs. Participants likely healthy adults; abstract describes original fMRI research (not a review). Sufficient info to include for full-text review.

fMRI study of emotional prosody (social communication) including a control group of healthy participants; meets social-related fMRI focus. Abstract does not specify participant ages (17–65), so include for full-text review to confirm age range and other details.

fMRI study of impression formation (social cognition) comparing people vs objects in healthy adult participants; directly examines social processing; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social decision-making from faces (affective processing) that reports results for males and females and compares individuals with ASD; includes healthy participants and matches social-related processing constructs. Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study of social perception (viewing social vs nonsocial images) including a healthy comparison group (n=14); meets social-processing and fMRI criteria. Ages not reported in abstract, so include for full-text to confirm age range and other eligibility.
Narrative review of the neurobiology of social phobia (1998). It is not a primary fMRI study and does not report functional MRI data from humans performing social tasks. Exclude as a review article.

fMRI study examining Theory of Mind/social cognition using a movie-based task (MASC), directly addressing social-related processing. Abstract implies healthy participants but does not specify ages/health; therefore include for full-text review to confirm participant demographics and eligibility.

Abstract lacks details on imaging methods, participant groups (healthy adults), and whether a social-related task was used. Title/abstract focus on autism and reward but provide insufficient information to determine eligibility; include for full-text review.

fMRI study in healthy volunteers performing social-cognitive tasks (emotion identification and attribution), addressing perception/understanding of others. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract lacks explicit participant ages; include for full-text to confirm demographics.

fMRI study in healthy adults assessing decisions to read vs share news articles; examines social-related processes (self-related processing, perspective-taking, social valuation). Meets inclusion: functional MRI during a social task and involves social cognition in healthy adults. Not a review.

fMRI study with human participants assessing mirror responses during action observation/execution after sensorimotor training, which relates to perception/understanding of others (social cognition). Participants are healthy humans; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI study with 78 healthy adult participants performing a narrative-reading task that probes responses to ‘protected values’—a social-cognitive/moral processing paradigm. Brain regions cited (mPFC, TPJ, posterior medial cortex) indicate social understanding processes. No exclusion criteria met; not a review. Sufficient information in abstract to include for full review.

Abstract does not specify whether fMRI was task-based social processing or resting-state, nor whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Because information is insufficient to determine eligibility from the abstract alone, include for full-text review.

Participants are adolescents (age range 11.1–15.5). Meta-analysis requires at least one healthy adult group aged 17–65; the abstract reports no adult participants. Therefore the study does not meet the age criterion for inclusion.

fMRI study examining implicit interpersonal space (affiliation-related social processing) during task contrasting social vs non-social stimuli. Human participants in a double-blind placebo-controlled design (presumably healthy adults). Meets inclusion criteria of fMRI during social-related task in healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis.

This is a conceptual/primer article discussing principles of brain-imaging and social neuroscience; the abstract does not report any original fMRI data or a functional MRI task with human participants. It appears to be a review/commentary rather than an eligible primary fMRI study.

fMRI study in 15 expert practitioners who viewed film clips of people in distress and used compassion meditation or reappraisal to modulate responses. This targets social processing (perception/understanding of others; affiliation) in healthy adults; no exclusion criteria met.

fMRI study using one-shot anonymous prisoner's dilemma (social decision-making) examining neural correlates of social cognition in prosocial vs proself participants. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and meets social-related task criterion. Not a review/meta-analysis.

This is a review article summarizing neuroimaging findings in autism rather than an original fMRI study of healthy adults. Exclusion criterion (systematic reviews/meta-analyses) applies; additionally, focus is on autistic patients rather than a healthy 17–65 adult sample.

Participants are two young children with autism spectrum disorder, not healthy adults aged 17–65. Although fMRI and social stimuli were used, the sample does not include a healthy adult group, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with healthy adult native Japanese participants performing communicative (social) vs descriptive speech tasks; examines social communication neural correlates (social-related processing). Meets inclusion criteria.

This is a resting-state fMRI study; no task-based social processing was performed. Although it includes healthy controls, the study does not involve participants performing a social-related task, so it fails the inclusion criterion requiring task-based fMRI of social processing.

Abstract assesses facial emotion processing (a social-related task) and explicitly includes healthy subjects; 'neurofunctional' suggests imaging measures. However, the abstract does not explicitly state fMRI nor report participant ages. Include for full-text review to confirm that an fMRI task was used and healthy participants are within 17–65.

fMRI study of human participants performing social-related task (perception of affective vocalisations/social communication). Appears to involve healthy adults, though ages not specified in abstract; include for full-text review to confirm age and health eligibility.

fMRI study with 37 healthy adult participants performing a social-communication task (evaluating whether they felt addressed). Targets social processing constructs and reports neural activations. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Study participants are adolescents (depressed and healthy adolescents). The review requires healthy adult participants aged 17–65; the abstract does not indicate an adult sample meeting this age range, so the population criterion is not met.

Functional MRI study examining neural responses to biological vs scrambled motion (nonverbal social stimuli), directly addressing social processing. Appears to involve healthy human participants; however participant ages are not specified in the abstract. Include for full-text review to confirm sample age and health status.

fMRI experiment investigating social cognition (person perception and mentalising) in human participants; involves a social-related task (linking bodies/names with trait statements). No indication it is a review/meta-analysis and likely uses healthy adult participants. Meets inclusion criteria; include for full-text review.

Abstract reports fMRI assessment of amygdala responsiveness to social-phobia-related verbal stimuli (a social-related task) and includes matched healthy control participants alongside patients, satisfying inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.
fMRI study of social-related processing (self-referential/valenced self vs other task) in healthy adult women (N=20). Meets inclusion (social task, healthy participants). No exclusion criteria met.

Study reports structural MRI volumetric analysis (manual tracing) of the fusiform gyrus in 22q11.2 deletion syndrome vs controls; no functional MRI or task-based social processing reported. Does not meet fMRI social-task inclusion criterion.

Functional MRI study conducted while participants made social attributions (perception/understanding of others). Appears to involve healthy adult participants and directly examines social processing (DMPFC). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.

This is an overview/narrative review of social neuroscience and psychiatry describing prior fMRI work rather than reporting original fMRI data from a cohort of healthy adults performing social tasks; it does not meet the primary fMRI study inclusion criterion.

Task involved fMRI during an emotional classification task using faces and voices (social perception/understanding of others). Participants appear to be healthy adults. Study is empirical fMRI, not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study investigating self-referential recollection in mPFC (conceptual vs agentic self), directly addressing social-cognitive processing (Perception/Understanding of Self). Involves human participants and is not a review. Ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text confirmation of participant age/health.

This is an editorial/introductory article for a special issue, not a primary empirical fMRI study. Abstract provides no methods, participants, or any fMRI task data; it summarizes multiple papers. Does not meet inclusion criterion of an fMRI scan during a social task.

fMRI study examining social expectancy violations along warmth and competence—clearly a social-related task involving perception/understanding of others. Appears to be original research with human participants (likely healthy adults) and not a review. Meets inclusion criteria; age not specified in abstract but sufficient for inclusion and full-text can confirm demographics.
Participants are children (ages 7–13); the review requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 17–65. Does not meet the adult age inclusion criterion.

fMRI study of social cue processing (fearful faces with direct/averted gaze) in adults; includes a matched healthy control group (26 adults) within target age range; task involves social perception/communication. Not a review.

Published in a review journal and abstract discusses synthesis of individual fMRI studies rather than reporting original fMRI data. This appears to be a review/meta-analysis, which meets the exclusion criterion.
Participants are children (ASD and typically developing), not adults aged 17–65; no group of healthy adults present. Therefore does not meet the age-based inclusion criterion for the review.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social exchange/ToM processing (social-related task). However the abstract does not specify participant health status or ages. Include for full-text review to confirm at least one group of healthy adults (17–65).

Abstract reports neural activations during the ultimatum game and developmental changes but does not specify the imaging modality (fMRI) or participant ages. Because it is unclear whether there is a healthy adult group (ages 17–65) and the method, include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Study uses fMRI to examine facial emotion processing (social perception/communication), matching the review objective. Abstract does not explicitly state whether healthy control participants (age 17–65) were included; because this is unclear but likely contains controls, include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI was used in healthy adults while participants processed idiographic negative self-beliefs and implemented emotion-regulation strategies, addressing perception/understanding of self (a social-related construct). Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in healthy adults (N=23, ages within 17–65) performing a social judgment task (evaluating social dominance in faces), directly addressing social processing. Not a review or meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria.

The study reports fMRI in patients with bipolar disorder and improvement in recognition of happy faces after EPO; the abstract does not mention any healthy control group. Inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group (age 17–65).

fMRI study investigating attentional orienting by gaze cues (social) and arrow cues, addressing social-related processing (perception/understanding of others/social communication). Abstract does not state participant health/ages, but no exclusion criteria met. Insufficient participant detail for certainty, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and ages.

fMRI study examining third-party punishment engages mentalizing and central-executive networks—social cognition/perception of others—conducted in healthy participants. Abstract does not report participant ages; include for full-text review to confirm age range and details.

The abstract reports fMRI data collected in a chronic traumatic brain injury population with no mention of a healthy control group. The meta-analysis requires at least one group of healthy participants (age 17–65); this study does not meet that inclusion criterion.

Abstract appears to be a review of mirror neuron dysfunction in ASD and summarizes evidence from fMRI, TMS, and EEG but does not state original fMRI data in healthy adults (ages 17–65). Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to determine whether primary fMRI data from healthy adult participants are reported.

Abstract reports task-based fMRI activation for social processing (among other domains) in a large Human Connectome Project cohort (n=787). HCP participants are healthy adults within the target age range, and this is an original fMRI study (not a review), so it meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using behavioral modeling and multivariate decoding during altruistic (prosocial) and dietary choice tasks; reports social-related neural processing (prosocial attribute encoding in precuneus and TPJ). Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is not a review.

Participants are adolescent girls recruited from childhood longitudinal data (not adults). Inclusion requires at least one group of healthy participants aged 17–65; this study’s sample is underage, so it does not meet the age criterion. Therefore exclude.

fMRI study examining mental state decoding (social cognition) using the 'Reading the Mind in the Eyes' task in native Japanese and white American adult participants. Participants are healthy adults and the task is clearly social-related. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for the review.

Empirical task-based fMRI study in healthy adults examining social perception/mentalizing (perception of others/animacy). It reports original fMRI data (not a review/meta-analysis) and fits the social-related processing constructs; thus meets inclusion criteria.

Original fMRI study with 30 healthy adult participants investigating gaze perception and action control—clearly a social-related task (gaze/social cognition, TPJ connectivity). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining brain responses to social auditory cues (one vs two people walking) indicating social interaction/affective processing. This fits the review objective of social-related fMRI in humans. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health status, so include for full-text review to confirm sample meets criteria.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants observing an expert demonstrator; tasks probe perception/understanding of others (motor resonance, mentalizing). Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults; not a review.

This article is an overview/review of molecular neuroimaging studies (a review), not an original fMRI study of healthy adults performing social tasks. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study using a social interaction (virtual ball-tossing) task probing social exclusion/inclusion; includes a healthy control group (n=20). Addresses social processing in adults. Age range not specified in abstract, so full-text can confirm exact ages.

Abstract reports fMRI hemodynamic responses to child stimuli (social cognition), meeting the social-related fMRI criterion. However, participant health status and ages (17–65) are not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

This study examines piano-based cognitive rehabilitation in patients with mild traumatic brain injury (no healthy adult group reported) and uses fMRI for neural plasticity/cognitive outcomes rather than a social-processing task. Does not meet inclusion criteria of social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

The fMRI task involved repeating real words and pseudowords (speech production/motor task) with no indication of social-related processing or social communication context. Although participants are healthy, the study does not address social processing as required for inclusion.

fMRI study explicitly used a social approval task (social-related processing) and included a healthy control group (n=15) alongside schizophrenia patients. Participants were scanned during the task; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

This is a review article discussing fMRI data in human and macaque infants and theoretical mechanisms; it is not an original fMRI study in healthy adults (ages 17–65). The abstract indicates a narrative review, meeting the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and not addressing adult participants.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of gaze effects on face processing—a social perception/communication task relevant to review. Not a review/meta-analysis. Participant health/ages are not specified in the abstract; per screening rules, include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample (17–65).

fMRI study reporting neural responses in pSTS to social interactions between agents; involves social perception processing in humans. Although abstract is truncated, it clearly examines social interaction perception in (presumably) healthy adults and meets inclusion criteria.

This is a theoretical/review paper discussing explanations for mirror-touch synesthesia. The abstract does not report an original fMRI study or functional MRI task data in healthy adults; meets exclusion criteria for reviews.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of prosodic (social communication) processing, which fits the review topic. However, it does not specify whether a healthy adult control group (ages 17–65) was included or participant ages. Insufficient detail to determine eligibility from abstract alone, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study examining theory of mind (social cognition) during task performance; includes a healthy control group alongside patients. Fits social-related processing in adults and is an original fMRI study, not a review.

Participants are children (one high-functioning autistic child, one Asperger’s child, three normal children). Inclusion requires at least one healthy participant aged 17–65. Age criterion not met, so exclude with high confidence.

Primary fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing communicative (social) vs descriptive speech tasks; directly investigates social communication neural correlates. Not a review/meta-analysis, meets inclusion criteria.

Primary fMRI study of empathy for pain (social cognition) including autistic and healthy control participants. Fits review objective (social-related processing) and includes a healthy control group. Abstract does not report participant ages; include for full-text review to confirm ages (17–65) and extract details.

The abstract indicates this is a review article summarizing psychopharmacological and fMRI research on noradrenaline, not an original fMRI study of participants. It meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses and provides sufficient information to exclude based on the abstract alone.

fMRI was used during social cognition tasks (eye gaze, face processing, theory of mind). Study includes a neurotypical control group (healthy participants). No exclusion criteria met. Age range not specified in abstract, so full text should be checked for participant ages (17–65).

Abstract reports two independent fMRI experiments using a visuo-tactile empathic judgment task assessing emotional egocentricity bias (social cognition/perception of others). Participants appear to be healthy adults and this is primary research (not a review). Sufficient information in abstract matches inclusion criteria.

Study used functional MRI in healthy male and female human participants to examine perception of social stimuli (spatial relations between two bodies/facing vs nonfacing), addressing social perception/understanding of others. Meets inclusion criteria; not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study of audiovisual speech perception (a social communication task) that includes age- and gender-matched healthy control participants. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults; full text can confirm ages and details.

Abstract mentions functional and structural brain correlates of ToM and empathy but does not specify methods, participant groups, or whether healthy controls (age 17–65) were scanned. Because information is insufficient to confirm inclusion criteria, include for full-text review to determine if fMRI social-task data from healthy adults are reported.

This study used structural MRI covariance analysis, not functional MRI during a social task. The review requires task-based fMRI in healthy adults; although controls are included, no fMRI social-task data are reported, so exclude.

fMRI study examining memory for neutral faces presented in goal-relevant vs goal-irrelevant social situations; task involves social processing (face identity, social context) and reports activation in social brain regions. No indication it is a review; likely healthy adult participants. Include for full-text to confirm ages/health.

fMRI study examining neural representations of observed actions (perception/understanding of others), using human participants—meets social-processing criterion. Abstract does not report participant ages/health explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm age range and health status.

The study includes a healthy control group (n=18) aged as adults, uses fMRI during social-related tasks (action observation/execution and action-understanding) probing mirror neuron system and theory-of-mind, and reports behavioral ToM (RME). It directly addresses social processing in healthy participants; no exclusion criteria met.

fMRI BOLD study administering a social-cognitive task (trustworthiness judgments of faces) and includes a healthy control group. Not a review/meta-analysis. Although participant ages are not specified in the abstract, the presence of healthy adult controls and relevant social processing task meets inclusion or warrants full-text review.

fMRI was used during a social task (social exclusion/inclusion) probing mentalizing and social processing in human participants. The sample are adolescents but ages/health status not specified in abstract; include for full-text review to confirm participants fall within 17–65 and are healthy.

Human fMRI study investigating neural representation of action meaning (mirror system) using auditory/semantic tasks; assesses perception/understanding of others’ actions — fits social-related processing. Participants appear to be healthy adults; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

Abstract describes empirical dfMRI (dyadic fMRI) investigating BOLD responses during reciprocal eye contact/social interaction, which aligns with social processing. However, participant health and age range are not specified in the abstract; full-text review is needed to confirm inclusion criteria (healthy adults 17–65).

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than task-based fMRI while participants performed social-cognitive tasks. Although healthy controls were included, the meta-analysis requires fMRI acquired during a social-related task. Therefore it does not meet the primary inclusion criterion.

Abstract reports brain imaging of self/other-reflection in schizophrenia, a social-processing task. It likely uses fMRI and is relevant, but the abstract doesn’t explicitly state fMRI or confirm healthy adult controls. No exclusion criteria met. Include for full-text review to verify modality and presence of healthy participants.

This article is a narrative review/perspective, not a primary fMRI study. The abstract describes field-level discussion without reporting original methods, participants, or fMRI data from healthy adult subjects performing social tasks, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in 22 healthy adult male participants performing social judgments (allocentric social hierarchies and social alliance), clearly a social-processing task in healthy adults within the eligible age range. Not a review or meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports neural hyperscanning during a social communication task in (presumably) healthy adults but does not specify the imaging modality. Inclusion requires fMRI; methods are unclear from the abstract. Include for full-text review to confirm whether a functional MRI was used.

Study examines executive function and frontoparietal-insular network connectivity in autism spectrum disorder, not social-related processing. Participants are clinical (ASD) rather than a healthy adult sample performing a social task. Does not meet the review’s requirement for fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults.

fMRI study uses a social interaction task (reaction-time competition with opponents) probing reactive aggression, which maps onto social processing/perception of others. Abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or ages; likely healthy adults but not confirmed. Include for full-text review to verify sample characteristics and ages.
All healthy participants are described as youth/typically developing children/adolescents, not adults aged 17–65; study therefore lacks a healthy adult group required for inclusion.

fMRI study investigating perception of emotions in dynamic crowds—a clear social processing task relevant to the review. Abstract does not state participant ages or explicit healthy status; likely healthy adults but not confirmed. Per screening rules, include for full-text review to verify participant characteristics and eligibility.

fMRI study of affective creativity (reappraisal of anger-evoking events) notes recruitment of default-mode network 'implicated in social cognition.' The abstract does not explicitly state whether stimuli/tasks were social or interpersonal, so inclusion is uncertain; recommend full-text review to confirm social-related processing.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than an fMRI task involving social-related processing. Inclusion requires task-based social fMRI; despite having healthy controls and social cognition measures, it does not meet the primary inclusion criterion.

Abstract reports fMRI data collected while healthy volunteers performed psychometric assessments of body-odour peptides (self vs non-self), a social/self-perception task related to mate choice. Activation in right middle frontal cortex reported; no patient groups mentioned.

Abstract reports simultaneous fMRI (with PET) probing mothers’ neural responses to their infants and connectivity within social-affiliation networks; participants are healthy adult mothers engaged in a social/attachment task. No exclusion criteria met.

fMRI study of social cognition (prediction of others' mental states) in human participants, matching review objective. Abstract does not report participant ages or explicitly state participants were healthy; information is insufficient to confirm eligibility, so include for full-text review to verify inclusion criteria.

The study investigates memory control and recognition processes using fMRI, with no mention of social-related tasks or constructs (e.g., affiliation, social communication, self/other perception). Although participants are healthy adults, the primary task is non-social, so it does not meet the review’s inclusion criteria.

Functional MRI was used while participants completed social tasks (charitable giving, EmpaToM) probing empathy, perspective taking, and attention—core social processes. Study involves human participants and is empirical (not a review). Fits inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing a social task (judgments of fairness/moral status from cooperative interactions). Targets perception/understanding of others and social cognition; not a review or meta-analysis. Satisfies inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes a review of ecstatic/orgasmic/musicogenic seizures and related phenomena, not a task-based fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. Participants appear to be patients/case studies; no social-related task or healthy control group is reported. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

The article is explicitly a review of the authors’ research program rather than an original fMRI study reporting primary data. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses despite being relevant to social perception.

Study reports fMRI while human participants observed human and robot agents experiencing pain/pleasure—a social cognition/empathy task (perception/understanding of others). Sample comprises 26 human participants (presumed healthy adults). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Primary fMRI research where participants considered others' mental states (social cognition/perception of others). Appears to include healthy adult participants and reports neural data; not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Participants are children (mean age 10.1 years), which falls well below the review's required adult age range of 17–65. Although an fMRI social task was used with healthy participants, the age criterion is not met.

fMRI study of social perception (face processing, attention to emotional valence) in human participants, addressing social processing. Abstract does not specify participant age or health status; include for full-text review to confirm participants meet age (17–65) and healthy criteria.

fMRI study with a non-clinical sample of 20 young adult males performing social-related tasks (empathic processing of realistic social interactions). Participants viewed first-person social interaction videos, addressing perception/understanding of others. Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

Study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (sighted controls and congenitally blind) performing voice-based identity and emotion recognition — social perception of others. This directly addresses social-related processing in humans and is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

fMRI was collected while human participants performed a social-cognitive (mind perception) task, and the study links neural activation to social attention behavior. The abstract describes healthy adult participants (no clinical groups mentioned) and it is an original empirical study, not a review.

Study used resting-state and structural MRI in boys (mean age ~11); no task-based fMRI during social-related processing. The healthy participants are children/adolescents, not an adult (17–65) healthy group required by inclusion criteria.

Study reports an fMRI emotional task and includes a healthy control group. The abstract does not clearly state the task is explicitly social-related (ambiguous), so include for full-text review to determine relevance to social processing.

Resting-state fMRI study in a sample of Major Depressive Disorder patients; no task-based social processing paradigm and no healthy adult group reported. Does not meet inclusion criteria of task-based fMRI in healthy adults.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no task). Inclusion requires task-based fMRI during a social-related task; although healthy controls are included, the absence of a social task means it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This article is a narrative review of adolescent neurobiology, not an original fMRI study reporting primary data. The exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews or meta-analyses; therefore it does not meet inclusion as an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults.

Abstract reports an fMRI-pupillometry study examining pupil mimicry effects on trust and recruitment of theory-of-mind network (precuneus, TPJ, STS, mPFC), i.e. social cognitive processing. Not a review; likely healthy adult participants. Include for full-text review.

fMRI experiment reported neural responses to viewing disfigured faces, a social perception task (perception/understanding of others). Participants appear to be human adults and no exclusion criteria apply. Abstract provides sufficient evidence of relevant social-related fMRI in (likely) healthy adults; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

All participants were recruited while entering psychotherapy for depression and/or anxiety; the abstract does not report any healthy control group. Inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group aged 17–65.
